In recent years the word “Chinaman” had been fading from common usage, and had already become pretty much just a reference to Chinese people by the end of the 19th century.  However, around the time of the Chinese Exclusion Act in the 1890s, the word was applied to all sorts of products (such as bean curd) to indicate a certain type of origin.  Soon it was being used in product advertising to specifically indicate Chinese products.  The result of this was that “Chinaman” began to be used as a derogatory term, to refer to cheap imitations of Chinese goods, although with much less frequency than “Chink”.
